All this talk of price gouging and ripoffs! No one considers that a textbook is a high-quality tool for learning, not a caffe latte.  In the 60's there were roughly a hundred publishers of college textbooks.  These businesses were of varying sizes and served varying markets.  Books were entirely in black and white and had a few maps and almost no illustrations.  (They were also challenging to read.)  All of those publishers have gone out of business or been absorbed, and now there are about 10 major textbook publishers who are struggling to stay alive.  If textbook publishing were all that profitable, most publishers wouldn't have gone out of business.  Anyone who thinks that the drivel that is free on the internet is equivalent to a college textbook will get the education they deserve.

#27 Alec – WHAT are you talking about? For multi-period investment, wherein amounts can be added or withdrawn along the way -- i.e., people's real-world serious investment -- there is NO SUCH THING as a “risk-free rate.” Even Sharpe, original champion of the risk-free rate, concedes this point. In his text, close to Bodie's in size, he devotes a whole large tiny-print page to it.

With the mythical “risk-free rate” excluded on account of nonexistence, it makes no sense to talk about “lowest terminal wealth” – unless you are referring to zero for every investment. What shape of the distribution’s low-side tail are you and your sources envisioning?

We are (at least I am) talking about viewing investments in terms of probabilities for dollar results relative to the investor’s dollar needs and goals. For long investment terms, most of the probability distribution of a very aggressive investment will represent wealths many times those of most of the probability distribution of a very conservative investment. (Due to compounding of the aggressive's higher return-rate mean!) For such an investment, it is commonly true that for the investor’s dollar needs and goals, the aggressive offers say 90% probability of meeting those dollar needs and goals, with most of its prospects much higher, while the conservative offers goal-meeting probability of (to the nearest whole percent) 0%. You and Bodie and whoever may consider the conservative less risky because of its lesser uncertainty, but I am on the investor’s side and would consider the aggressive investment less risky.

#26 Carl – Are you saying that in comparing investments in long-term RISK, we should consider differences in only uncertainties, and not differences in the means from which the uncertainties extend? I consider that to be on the side of the cartel of ivory tower investment professors, against the side of the investors. Probabilities for the investor’s dollar results are determined by the combination of (a) mean and (b) uncertainties above and below it. And over longer terms, the advantage of higher return-rate mean increasingly outweighs the disadvantage of larger return-rate standard deviation.

Dick Purcell

I spent 3 nights at the Romeo Hotel last fall and, how can I put this... it completely blew me away and exceeded my expectations. It is an ultra modern, boutique design hotel, which is not typical of Naples. However, it's so beautiful and oozing with style, I just fell in love with it. (They even had chairs made out of petrified wood from Mount Vesuvius in the elevator near my room!)

I travel to Naples about once a year for business and I remember when the hotel was just about to open. One of the taxi drivers actually pointed it out to me and seemed to be extremely proud of it, saying that it was to be "the finest hotel our city has ever seen". He was so proud of the place, you'd think he was one of the owners! Based on his enthusiasm, I figured, "what the heck?" and ended up booking a room upon my last trip. Glad I did!

- Charles

Great Saturday score for me. I had only one Google-Ned Vizzini. Listening to Red Sox-Rangers slugfest with Stratton story. Got Denny's as the first answer which shows that I will read ANYTHING. Was on the right wavelength for bestow, zeroed out, trimmers, and run riot. Took me longer than it should have to get rare bird; for some reason I thought it was rare duck.

Rangers have tied it up. Off I go to the puzzle archive.

With Saturday puzzles you solve them any way you can.

As an example, in this one there were some pretty straightforward clues at the beginning like 2 down which yielded ITALIANO and from there OLA for 19 Across was obvious and ITT for 23 Across made sense. 33 Across seemed certain to be SONATAS and from there, the whole northwest section began to fill nicely using these crossing letters.

A similar opening was available at the very end of the puzzle by filling in the EST portion of the clue which as "Most difficult to manage" clearly signaled the last 3 letters of the answer. The EST then gives you STET at 53 down which allows you to confidently fill in OMS at 52 across and then a reasonable guess at 56 across gives you the last 3 letters of the plane engine clue as JET and, once again a whole section begins to open up nicely.

Its not rocket science or glamorous perhaps but the bits and pieces do eventually tie the puzzle together and for me, when tackling a themeless Times puzzle, the acronym KISS, (KEEP IT SIMPLE STUPID), is always uppermost in my mind.

This stops one from agonizing over the answer to a clue like, say, "Man of one's dreams" until you have enough crossing letters to show you it is MORPHEUS.
Just one google, for JUDD Apatow.... but I was obsessed with finishing the rest on my own, though I'm supposed to be packing for an early start. Never mind, it was worth it! HUNKY-DORY!

Sweetsop (Annona squamosa), soursop (Annona muricata), custard apple (Annona reticulata) and cherimoya (Annona cherimola) are all somewhat similar, delicious fruits with custardy textures and wonderful aromatic flavors.  Soursop nectar is available canned in Salvadorean and other Latin markets as guanabana.  It has the texture of pear nectar but the wonderful combination of exotic fruit flavors that all these Annona species are famous for.  If you have such a market available, check out the guanabana.

I guess it's useful for headline writing, but "Detroit" is not a synonym for "auto industry executives."  It was rather disappointing to read about the balance sheets of two or three companies-- good news though it is-- rather than the fortunes of a city that's been through rough times.
We'll never wean ourselves from big SUVs because Americans are too goddamn fat to fit in a small car.

I'm glad the auto industry is doing well again in America. We need manufactoring in this country. It's great jobs, and it's national security. It doesn't matter how many billions you spend on the military, every nation knows that going to war needs manufacturing to support it. We would have lost world war 2 without the auto industry that became the defence industry during the war.

Germany, as reported today, has the best economy in Europe and is recovery very well.  Let's see, Germany rejected GM's application for a loan for its German unit, Opel, whereas the US dumped $57B down the toilet with GM...

mac 51, I will readily agree that Obama etc.'s actions deserve the credit for bailing out Detroit and I won't say that it's an entirely bad thing, to lose the auto industry in one fell swoop at that moment in economic history may have been a huge problem, but it's now time to turn the industry on its head and start producing a product that will be as innovative in the 21st century as the car was over one hundred years ago.

I don't believe Detroit can compete with the best foreign autos like Honda & Toyota. They would have to completely retool for the greater precisions needed to put out a decent product. Detroit's corruption, as far as I'm concerned, has been onging for so long now that it's probably terminal.

However, if Consumers Union reports good reliability after 5-6 years for a given model I might have to rethink.

What we need is not a better auto industry, or some marginally more efficient car. What is needed is to get people out of cars. This article describes an effort to keep people buying cars, and living the car lifestyle, when it's clearly not a good idea. Dragging it out this way is just bad news. We are continuing work on the booby trap that we have made of our society. People should be making buses, trains, and bicycles.

I was beginning to think Barrack Obama was guaranteed to be a one term president. Now I am convinced he has better than an even chance to win or even trounce the next republican candidate for president. The reason I am convinced is look at the stupid and imbecile reactions by the other side to the GM story. In the previous article many of the so called patriotic Americans responded who no doubt are the first ones to raise the flag decried this limited success story many stating they would never buy an American car. Where do they rather these cars be made, in germany? how about japan? Many had a visceral hatred for the unions because the union bosses are so called in the pocket of the democratic party but guess what folks, these union people that have lost their livelihood and are fighting for survival are your fellow Americans many of whom and their relatives are the first to fight and die for our country. Look at how many union members volunteered during the 9-11 crisis often at peril to their long term health. It is not rocket science to be able to figure out that if Michigan or Ohio does well then it makes it more likely that California or Texas or Oklahoma will do better because people in Ohio or Michigan will be able to purchase more goods from California, Texas or Oklahoma. I am convinced the republicans will do well in the midterm election or may even pick up the house and/or the senate however I am more convinced that once Americans see what they have what these people are really made of Obama will be in a good position to stage one of the most remarkable comeback in history. All he has to do is to watch these people shoot themselves in the foot.
Sounds like a Pyrrhic victory to me when unemployment in Detroit is at 30%.
